videoDescription: Atrial fibrillation happens when the heart beats at a very fast rate‚Äîtypically more than 100 beats per minute. videoTitle: Oncologist Shares Top Immunotherapies for Cancer Patients with David Hermel, MD | San Diego Health
videoDescription: In this video, San Diego Health host Susan Taylor speaks with Dr. David Hermel of Scripps Cancer Center about immunotherapy, a groundbreaking approach to fighting cancer. Unlike traditional treatments like chemotherapy, which affect both healthy and cancerous cells, immunotherapy precisely targets cancer cells by modifying the immune system. Immunotherapy is particularly effective for cancers like melanoma and may be combined with chemotherapy or radiation. Side effects are generally mild, resembling cold-like symptoms. At Scripps Cancer Center, multidisciplinary teams personalize treatments for optimal results. videoTitle: E-bike Safety for Older Adults with Walter Biffl, MD
videoDescription: The growing concern for environmentally friendly transportation, coupled with the skyrocketing popularity of electric bicycles, is making bicycles one of the top choices for getting around. videoTitle: The Benefits of Laser Treatment with Edward Ross, MD | San Diego Health

videoTitle: Early-Onset Alzheimer's Disease with Leonard Sokol, MD | San Diego Health
videoDescription: Nearly everyone struggles with remembering the name of an acquaintance or forgets what they were about to say. Such occasional forgetfulness is normal, but if it begins to interfere with everyday function, it may be due to Alzheimer‚Äôs. Alzheimer‚Äôs is a type of dementia that affects memory, thinking and behavior. Alzheimer‚Äôs disease typically develops after age 65. However, early-onset Alzheimer‚Äôs disease can begin much earlier, typically appearing in the 40s and 50s. In families who carry a genetic mutation predicting early-onset Alzheimer‚Äôs disease, individuals may develop symptoms in their 20s or 30s, although this is not common. In this video, San Diego Health host Susan Taylor talks with Leonard Sokol, MD, a neurologist at Scripps Clinic Torrey Pines and Scripps Clinic Encinitas, about early-onset Alzheimer‚Äôs. videoTitle: Heart Problems During Pregnancy with Poulina Uddin, MD and Sean Daneshmand, MD | San Diego Health
videoDescription: In this video, San Diego Health host Susan Taylor talks with Poulina Uddin, MD, a cardiologist at Scripps Clinic and Sean Daneshmand, MD, an OB-GYN at Scripps Clinic, about pregnancy and heart problems that can affect both mom and baby. ‚ÄúEating for two‚Äù is a common expression regarding pregnancy, but what about ‚Äùbeating for two‚Äù? When you‚Äôre pregnant, your heart is working extra hard to support an additional life. For some women, that extra work puts significant strain on their heart; in fact, developing heart problems during pregnancy is surprisingly common. videoTitle: The Risks of Pregnancy After 35 with Daniela Gomez, MD and Alex Fite | San Diego Health
videoDescription: In this video, San Diego Health host Susan Taylor talks about advanced maternal age pregnancy with Daniela Gomez, MD, an OB-GYN who specializes in maternal and fetal medicine at Scripps Clinic, and Alex Fite, a genetic counselor at the Scripps Perinatology Program. Just a few decades ago, getting pregnant after age 35 was relatively uncommon. More recently, though, a growing number of women in this age group are having babies or trying to become pregnant. This is known as advanced maternal age pregnancy. While the vast majority of these babies are born healthy, it‚Äôs important to know about the increased risks of pregnancy after 35 and how to prepare. videoTitle: Acne: Identifying Causes and Effective Treatment with Sophia Akhiyat, MD | San Diego Health
videoDescription: Acne is often associated with the teenage years, but this common skin condition also affects adults well into their 30s and 40s. According to the American Academy of Dermatology, up to 50 million Americans develop acne every year. There are different types of acne, and breakouts can range from mild to severe. Fortunately, effective acne treatments are available. In this video San Diego Health host Susan Taylor talks with Scripps dermatologist Sophia Akhiyat, MD, about acne causes and treatments. videoDescription: As we age, life can take a toll on our skin. Even if we do our best to avoid sun exposure and minimize stress, there‚Äôs no controlling gravity‚Äîover time, everyone‚Äôs skin will lose some elasticity and give way to wrinkles and sagging, especially on the face. Moreover, we tend to lose facial fat as we get older, so the skin not only drops but also deflates. Fortunately, you can address some effects of visibly aging skin without conventional facelift surgery. In this video, San Diego Health host Susan Taylor talks about the ‚Äúmini facelift‚Äù option with Salvatore Pacella, MD, a plastic surgeon with Scripps Clinic and division head of plastic and reconstructive surgery. videoTitle: Weight Loss with Medication or Surgery with Jennie Luna, MD and Mark Takata, MD | San Diego Health
videoDescription: For many people in the United States, trying to lose weight can feel like a losing battle. Every year, about 45 million Americans go on a diet and spend about $33 billion on weight-loss products. Some people do lose weight and keep it off, but others have little success or lose excess weight only to gain it back. When diets don‚Äôt work, weight loss medication or bariatric surgery may be options. videoTitle: What Can You Do As a Parent to Prevent Childhood Obesity? with Ann MacQuarrie, MD | San Diego Health
videoDescription: In this video, San Diego Health host Susan Taylor talks with Scripps pediatrician Ann MacQuarrie, MD, about why childhood obesity is on the rise and how to address it. Over the past few decades, obesity rates among children have risen steeply. In fact, almost 15 million children and adolescents ‚Äì roughly 2 out of every 10 kids ‚Äì are obese. Childhood obesity raises the risk of many health conditions, including type 2 diabetes, high blood pressure and respiratory illnesses, as well as back and joint problems. videoTitle: Sign and Symptoms of Autism with Megan Craig, MD | San Diego Health
videoDescription: In this video, San Diego Health host Susan Taylor talks with Scripps pediatrician Megan Craig, MD, about autism symptoms and treatment options. How your child plays, speaks, behaves and meets other developmental ‚Äúmilestones‚Äù by certain ages can offer important insight into their development. No two children develop at exactly the same rate ‚Äì not even twins ‚Äì but some children who don‚Äôt meet developmental milestones may have autism. Commonly referred to as autism spectrum disorder (ASD), autism refers to a broad range of conditions characterized by challenges with social skills, repetitive behaviors, speech and nonverbal communication. videoTitle: HIV and AIDS Discussion with Dr. Brian Kim | San Diego Health
videoDescription: In this video, San Diego Health host Susan Taylor talks with Scripps family medicine doctor Brian Kim, MD, about HIV and AIDS. When human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) was first diagnosed in the 1980s, it was considered a fatal disease. HIV attacks the body's immune system and can make it vulnerable to acquired immune deficiency syndrome or AIDS, a collection of conditions that put the body at high risk for life-threatening infections and cancer. There is still no cure for HIV, but advancements over the past several decades have resulted in treatments that help stop its progress, so it is no longer considered a death sentence. videoTitle: What Causes Gestational Diabetes in Pregnancy with Dr. Roman Starikov | San Diego Health
videoDescription: Pregnancy-related diabetes develops in 6 to 9% of pregnant women. In this condition, the placenta releases hormones that prevent the mother from producing enough insulin to lower her blood sugar levels, which is harmful to the baby. In this video, host Susan Taylor discusses the symptoms, risk factors and treatment of gestational diabetes with Roman Starikov, MD, a Scripps obstetrician and gynecologist specializing in maternal and fetal medicine. videoTitle: How Does Your Diet Affect Diabetes? with Dr. Samantha Harris | San Diego Health
videoDescription: The primary source of energy in your body is glucose, also known as blood sugar. The pancreas produces a hormone called insulin that regulates glucose levels in the body. Diabetes can occur if your pancreas can't produce enough insulin to keep blood sugar levels from becoming too high. Although there is no cure for diabetes, it can be managed with medication and a healthy lifestyle, including diet. In this video, host Susan Taylor discusses diabetes and diet with Samantha Harris, MD, an endocrinologist specializing in diabetes and weight management at Scripps Clinic. videoTitle: What Is a Hernia and How Can You Treat It? with Dr. Mark Sherman | San Diego Health
videoDescription: Although hernias are associated with sports injuries and overexertion, they can occur for various reasons - the primary factor being sudden sustained effort. videoTitle: High Blood Pressure (Hypertension) During Pregnancy With Dr. Sean Daneshmand | San Diego Health
videoDescription: High blood pressure during pregnancy can cause complications for both mother and baby. Pregnant women are increasingly suffering from high blood pressure and other related conditions, such as obesity and diabetes, which may cause problems with the heart, lungs or brain. A major concern is preeclampsia, which can occur at any time during pregnancy or after delivery for as long as six weeks. In this video, host Susan Taylor and medical director for the Scripps Clinic Perinatology Program, Dr. Sean Daneshmand, discuss hypertension in pregnancy. Learn more: http://www.scripps.org/7288y 0:45 - Why is high blood pressure (hypertension) on the rise during pregnancy? 1:09 - What are the symptoms of high blood pressure? 1:28 - How does high blood pressure put the mom and her unborn baby at risk? 2:11 - What is preeclampsia? 2:43 - How can you control high blood pressure during pregnancy? 3:55 - Should you have a conversation with your doctor about high blood pressure and hypertension before getting pregnant? 4:21 - What if you have high blood pressure before getting pregnant? 5:02 - After you've given birth, and if you have high blood pressure during pregnancy, what are you at risk for? 5:50 - How do you monitor your blood pressure before, during and after pregnancy? 6:21 - How does the Scripps Clinic Perinatology program help high-risk patients? 7:35 - Final thoughts

videoTitle: Scripps Clinic Micrographic Surgery and Dermatologic Oncology Fellowship
videoDescription: The one-year Scripps Clinic Micrographic Surgery and Dermatologic Oncology Fellowship Program helps trainees master the complexities of Mohs and other dermatologic surgeries. Fellows learn Mohs laboratory procedures and prepare sections using both the fresh and fixed techniques. Fellows may also participate in other dermatologic procedures, such as hair transplants, dermabrasions, chemical peels, scar revisions, cosmetic procedures, podiatric surgeries, particle resurfacing, cutaneous laser surgery and tumescent liposuction. Please note: Some of the footage and images in this video were taken prior to the COVID-19 pandemic. Scripps is currently following all CDC guidelines, and has implemented special protocols, to keep our facilities safe for our patients and staff. videoTitle: Scripps Clinic and Scripps Green Hospital Endocrinology, Diabetes and Metabolism Fellowship Program
videoDescription: Our fellowship at Scripps Clinic and Scripps Green Hospital is a two-year ACGME-accredited program offering broad training. videoDescription: Got pain in your hip? If you're a young, active adult, it might be time to consider hip arthroscopy. videoTitle: Scripps E-Visit Tutorial
videoDescription: Scripps E-Visits provide medical advice about minor problems (such as a UTI or cold) without having to go to the doctor's office. videoTitle: Scripps Plastic Surgeon Manish Champaneria, MD
videoDescription: Dr. Champaneria has clinical interest in cosmetic surgery, reconstructive surgery, transgender surgery, lymphedema surgery and microsurgery. See his bio: http://bit.ly/2VGw6Sk For people seeking cosmetic plastic surgery, Dr. Champaneria offers a wide range of procedures, including breast augmentation, reduction and lift. He also offers body contouring services, such as abdominoplasty, advanced liposuction and fat transfer procedures, including Brazilian buttock lift and breast revision. He performs facial rejuvenation procedures such as facelift, neck lift and brow/eyelid lift, in addition to injectable treatments and fillers. Understanding his patient's needs and self-improvement goals is paramount to Dr. Champaneria. He is passionate about helping people reach their physical ideal. His practice is dedicated to providing a high level of patient care while offering the latest treatment options in cosmetic and reconstructive surgery.

videoTitle: Scripps Health: What You Need to Know About Your New Medicare Card
videoDescription: Ten things you should know about your new medicare cards. For more information about Medicare visit: 1. New Medicare cards will be mailed automatically. 2. If you need to update your address, visit your mySocial Security account. 3. Your new card will have a unique Medicare number. 4. Your new number will protect you from identity theft. 5. Medicare will never reach out to you for private information. If someone contacts you asking for private information, hang up and call 1-800-MEDICARE 6. Your Medicare coverage will stay the same. 7. Health care providers will ask for your new Medicare card, so carry it with you. 8. Only give your new number to health care providers, insurers, and people you trust when you need care. 9. If you have a Medicare Advantage Plan your advantage ID is your main card for medicare, keep both cards with you. 10. If you have a Medicare drug plan, be sure to keep that card as well.

caption: false

videoTitle: Scripps Oncologist Explains New Breast Cancer Study with KUSI
videoDescription: Recent study reveals most women with early-stage breast cancer can safely skip chemotherapy without hurting their chances of beating the disease. Dr. Ray Lin discusses the groundbreaking study. Need a mammogram? Learn more here: http://bit.ly/BcMyt This is the largest study ever done of breast cancer treatment, and the results are expected to spare up to 70,000 patients a year in the United States and many more elsewhere the ordeal and expense of these drugs. The study gave 10,273 patients a genetic test, which uses a tumor sample to measure the presence of certain genes associated with higher likelihood of recurrence. Women are given scores based on this test, classifying them as being either at high risk of recurrence, intermediate risk, or low risk. About 17 percent of women had high-risk scores and were advised to have chemo. The 16 percent with low-risk scores now know they can skip chemo, based on earlier results from this study. The new results are on the 67 percent of women at intermediate risk. All had surgery and hormone therapy, and half also got chemo. After nine years, 94 percent of both groups were still alive, and about 84 percent were alive without signs of cancer, so adding chemo made no difference.
tags: health,scripps health,scripps,san diego,california,healthcare,health care,doctor,breast cancer,chemotherapy,chemotherapy for breast cancer,breast cancer treatments,la jolla,scripps green,radiation oncology,oncology,breast cancer study,new breast cancer study,kusi news

videoTitle: Heart Attack Survivor Pays It Forward After Lifesaving Care
videoDescription: Heart attack survivor B Verde talks about the extraordinary care she received at Scripps and her effort to help other women fight heart disease. Learn more about B's story: http://bit.ly/BVsStoryYT It‚Äôs a common misconception that heart disease is a men‚Äôs issue. In fact, it kills nearly twice as many women as all forms of cancer combined. Still, many women don‚Äôt think about their heart health. That needs to change. Sometimes women don‚Äôt know they‚Äôre having a heart attack. Aside from chest pain or a cold sweat, their symptoms aren‚Äôt the same as those typically seen in men. Women tend to have subtler symptoms. Just ask Bertha ‚ÄúB‚Äù Verde, age 54. Many heart attack symptoms in women are easily mistaken for a common ailment and can sometimes appear up to a month before the attack itself. They include: Fatigue or weakness Unusual tiredness Pressure or tightness in the center of the chest Sudden dizziness Shortness of breath Pain that spreads to the upper body, neck, or jaw Unusual sweating, nausea, or vomiting Problems sleeping

videoTitle: Cancer Survivor Celebrates by Dancing with Scripps Doctor
videoDescription: Cancer survivor, Steve Valentine and Scripps Health oncoclogist, Irene Hutchins, kick off Scripps Health Cancer Survivor Month #NCSD2017 by fulfilling a bedside pact with a ballroom dance. Learn more about Scripps cancer care: http://bit.ly/SHCancerCare. When the Scripps Health oncologist and her patient discovered they shared a common connection as national champion ballroom dancers, she promised him they would dance when he recovered from an aggressive form of lymphoma - a pact she said visibly uplifted his spirits. The pair share their story during Scripps Health's Cancer Survivors Day at Scripps Green Hospital in La Jolla, CA as a tribute to the care team who made a miracle happen and an inspirational message to show others you can bounce back. Life after cancer is a beautiful thing.

videoTitle: Certification Marks Scripps as Leader in Restless Legs Syndrome
videoDescription: Scripps neurologist J. Steven Poceta, MD, is a leader in the diagnosis and treatment of restless legs syndrome (RLS). As one of only eight certified centers in the nation, and the only one in Southern California, the Scripps Clinic Viterbi Family Sleep Center offers the latest in restless legs syndrome diagnostics and therapy. Due to the chronic nature of the disorder and potential treatment side effects, the care of RLS patients often requires close, long-term clinical management. The sleep center is located on the Scripps Green Hospital campus in La Jolla, with services in both the hospital and the adjoining Anderson Outpatient Pavilion at Scripps Clinic Torrey Pines.

videoTitle: Scripps Heart Care Saves Life of MLB Hall of Famer Rod Carew
videoDescription: To anyone else who will listen to him, Carew wants to say, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs important to get your heart checked out and listen to what you doctor says. Take care of your heart, it‚Äôs as simple as that.‚Äù Learn more about heart care with Scripps: Major League Baseball Hall of Famer and All-Star Rod Carew was diagnosed with heart failure after suffering a massive heart attack in 2015 and subsequently underwent an implantation of a left ventricular assist device (LVAD) at Scripps Health in San Diego. Thanks to the LVAD procedure he was able to maintain his health until he was able to receive a new heart. ‚ÄúI am grateful to be here today, living back home with my family, doing many of the things that make life special and preparing to join the heart transplant list, all thanks to the tremendous care I received at Scripps,‚Äù Carew said. ‚ÄúMy second chance at life is a testament to the cutting-edge treatment and the genuine care for me and my family provided by the surgeons, my cardiologists and all the staff at Prebys Cardiovascular Institute and Scripps Encinitas.‚Äù

This FDA-approved technology, called the WATCHMAN‚Ñ¢ LAA Closure device, is a proven alternative to long-term warfarin therapy in patients with non-valvular atrial fibrillation. The WATCHMAN device is intended to prevent the migration of blood clots that form in the LAA that cause stroke.

videoDescription: A less invasive alternative to open-heart surgery at Scripps Health gave Lester Tenney his life back. The transcatheter aortic heart valve replacement (TAVR) procedure offered him a treatment option for heart valve replacement that was less invasive, safer and more cost effective than open heart surgery.

videoTitle: Honor Loren Nancarrow's Memory and Support a Healing Garden at Scripps Health
videoDescription: Loren Nancarrow passed away peacefully on Saturday, Dec. 28, surrounded by his family. When he was diagnosed with brain cancer in February 2013, his thoughts -- as always -- immediately focused on other people. He knew he wanted to create a legacy that would help other cancer patients in San Diego. Susan Taylor, a longtime friend and current executive director of external affairs at Scripps Health, worked closely with Loren and his family to help him envision how they could help other cancer patients heal. Learn more at http://www.scripps.org/loren.

videoTitle: Learn How to Protect Your Kids from Sudden Cardiac Arrest
videoDescription: Sudden cardiac arrest is a rare but potentially deadly condition. The only way to prevent sudden cardiac arrest is to know if your child is at risk through a simple EKG. videoTitle: Scripps-led Study Shows New Drug Helps Bridge Stent Patients to Cardiac Surgery
videoDescription: New findings from a research study led by physicians at Scripps Health reveal that the drug cangrelor has the unique properties of achieving very fast blood thinning effects when needed to protect from heart attacks, but also dissipates rapidly so patients can undergo surgery without the excessive bleeding often associated with blood thinning medications.

videoTitle: Difficult Breast Cancer Decision Made Clearer Through Genetics
videoDescription: A year and a half ago, Jennifer Sobajian noticed a lump in her breast -- and since then, has had a mastectomy and reconstructive surgery at Scripps. Jennifer turned to Dr. Mary Wilde, surgeon and medical director of Scripps Polster Breast Care Center for help navigating her choices--including a decision to have genetic testing. videoTitle: Clinical Trial Tests Insulin Pump to Manage Diabetes Better
videoDescription: Diagnosed with Type 1 diabetes 35 years ago, Joan Reder is enrolled in the Star 3 Clinical Trial at Scripps Whittier Diabetes Institute. As part of the trial, she now has a digital insulin pump with a sensor to monitor her glucose levels. She used to take up to 7 insulin shots a day to manage her blood sugar. Today, that's down to one every three days. Research like this is helping patients transform the way they manage their diabetes every day. For more information on research at Scripps Health, see http://www.scripps.org/research.
tags: scripps,scripps health,physicians,san diego,health care,Diabetes,Type I,Type II,Type 1,Type 2,insulin,insulin pump,blood sugar,A1C
caption: false

videoTitle: Putting Heart Attacks on Ice
videoDescription: Al Fields had a heart attack while running. He says he doesn't remember much about that day. But when he woke up four days later at Scripps, he discovered his body had been cooled drastically -- placed in therapeutic hypothermic state to help him heal. See how rapidly lowering body temperature can help patients survive. For more information on heart care at Scripps, visit http://www.scripps.org/heart .

videoTitle: Minimally Invasive Brain Surgery
videoDescription: A few months ago, Clive Essakow underwent a minimally invasive procedure at Scripps to repair a dural fistula -- an abnormal connection between an artery and a vein in his brain. He just completed the Alcatraz Invitational swim at his best time ever. For more information on Minimally Invasive Robotic Surgery at Scripps, visit http://www.scripps.org/robotics .

videoTitle: Targeting Bladder Cancer With Robotic Surgery
videoDescription: Steve Jamison turned to Carol Salem, medical director of Scripps Minimally Invasive Robotic Surgery Program, to discuss treatment options when he faced a diagnosis of bladder cancer. Robotic surgery allowed Dr. Salem to remove the diseased organ and create a new bladder from a section of intestine, then placed back into his body -- all with minimal incisions and blood loss. See the surgical robot in action.

videoTitle: Living Kidney Transplant Transforms Two Lives
videoDescription: Scripps is one of Southern California's premier transplant centers and has provided living kidney and liver transplants to patients such as Mike Sedgewick for more than 20 years. Mike, a pastor, received a living kidney donation from one of his congregation members, Gary Wasserman, after receiving dialysis treatments for more than four years. For more information on organ and cell transplantation at Scripps, visit http://www.scripps.org/transplant .

videoTitle: Scripps Doctors Use Handheld Echocardiography to See Inside the Heart
videoDescription: Scripps is the first health care system to give physicians Vscan -- a revolutionary "pocket echo" -- to see inside the hearts of patients like Terry Dutton, who had aortic valve replacement several years ago. videoTitle: Eating Healthy on a Budget Takes Planning
videoDescription: According to a recent study from the University of Washington, following the new dietary guidelines can add almost 10% to your food bill. We can either be a victim of high costs of food or we can take some actions to decrease that cost. Scripps Hospital nutritionist, Megan Boitano says eating healthy on a budget takes planning, whether shopping the produce aisle or meat department. The meat is usually more expensive than fruits and vegetable, so looking for portion side, stalking up, and cutting coupons are all ways to eat healthier and save money.
tags: Scripps Health,Scripps,Healthy Eating,Scripps Health San Diego,KNSD,nutrition tips
caption: false

videoTitle: An Interview with Philanthropist Conrad Prebys
videoDescription: Noted San Diego developer and philanthropist Conrad Prebys has announced that he will be donating $45 million to help build the Prebys Cardiovascular Institute. This is the largest donation in the history of Scripps Health. Unparalleled in its kind, Prebys Cardiovascular Institute will combine the best of innovation and technology to offer people throughout San Diego, and beyond, the most progressive cardiovascular care available.

videoTitle: Scripps Celebrates Cardiovascular Institute with Groundbreaking
videoDescription: On Jun 21, 2011, Scripps Health celebrated the groundbreaking of the new Scripps Cardiovascular Institute with a groundbreaking ceremony. Scheduled to be completed by 2015, Scripps Cardiovascular Institute is the first phase of a 25-year plan to redesign the campus of Scripps Memorial Hospital La Jolla as a regional medical campus for San Diego.

caption: false

videoTitle: Scripps Cardiovascular Institute
videoDescription: Construction is underway for the Scripps Cardiovascular Institute, a new heart care facility to be located on the campus of Scripps Memorial Hospital La Jolla. This new heart care facility will include108 in-patient private rooms, 60 intensive care rooms, four operating suites and two hybrid operating rooms. This is the first of three new hospital towers to be built on the campus of Scripps Memorial Hospital La Jolla. For more information visit www.scripps.org/lajollaplan or call 1-800-SCRIPPS.
tags: health care,healthcare,heart care,scripps,san diego,cardiology,cardiologist,construction,seismic retrofitting
caption: false

videoTitle: Scripps Memorial Hospital La Jolla 25-Year Master Plan
videoDescription: Construction has begun on the Scripps Cardiovascular Institute, the first phase in a 25-year master plan to redesign Scripps Memorial Hospital La Jolla into a regional medical campus. In addition to the destination heart care facility of the Scripps Cardiovascular Institute, the hospital campus will include two additional hospital towers, two medical office buildings and a central energy plant. The existing hospital will be razed and rebuilt to meet state seismic standards. For more information visit www.scripps.org/lajollaplan or call 1-800-SCRIPPS.

videoTitle: Heart Valve Surgery Helps Retired Teacher

videoTitle: 120 Years of Scripps Mercy: Press Conferences
videoDescription: On Friday, July 9, 2010 Scripps Mercy Hospital officially marked 120 years of service as San Diego County's largest and longest established hospital. videoTitle: Scripps La Jolla Performs 1st of a Kind Surgery in San Diego
videoDescription: Linda Sounart has suffered from chronic heartburn for almost 20 years. The 62-year-old Carlsbad resident has tried modifying her diet, popping antacids by the handful, and taking a variety of prescription medications. But on May 6., all that changed when Sounart became one of the first patients in San Diego County to undergo new "incisionless" procedure called Esophyx that promised to bring her instant relief. The surgery was performed by Dr. Mark Sherman at Scripps Memorial Hospital La Jolla.

videoDescription: SDSU Aztecs womens basketball coach Beth Burns is helping raise awareness about breast cancer, the most common cancer among women. videoTitle: Facts and Myths About Supplements: A Scripps Wellness Day Seminar with Dr. David Leopold
videoDescription: Americans spend in excess of $20 billion annually on herbal and dietary supplements‚Äîand most of the time, they do so without the guidance of a health care practitioner. Does fish oil really help with depression and heart disease? Will flaxseed reduce inflammation? Can ginseng boost energy? Should everyone be taking multi-vitamins? How do you judge a supplements quality? Are generic low cost brands just as good as name brands? These and many other questions will be answered during Dr. Leopolds presentation. See http://www.scripps.org/c__wellness-day-2009__integrative-medicine__seminars for more.
tags: Scripps,Health,wellness day,integrative,medicine,David Leopold,family medicine,primary care
caption: false

videoTitle: Stress Management for Busy People: A Scripps Wellness Day Seminar with Dr. Raneth Heng
videoDescription: Join Raneth Heng, M.D., from Scripps Center for Integrative Medicine to learn how to improve the stress response and reduce the harmful effects of stress. Chronic outpouring of stress hormones can cause fatigue, weight gain, memory loss, lack of concentration, irritability, anger, frustration, illness and frequent headaches. Chronic stress can deplete the immune system and increase risk of heart disease, cancer and other health problems. Dr. Heng will help participants assess their personal relaxation needs and identify and overcome barriers to relaxation in order to achieve optimum health. See http://www.scripps.org/c__wellness-day-2009__integrative-medicine__seminars for more.
tags: Scripps,Health,wellness day,integrative,medicine,Raneth Heng,primary care,family medicine
caption: false

videoTitle: Reversing Heart Disease: A Scripps Wellness Day Seminar with Dr. Chris Suhar
videoDescription: Whether you've already had a heart attack, want to reduce your risk of developing heart problems or are simply interested in enhancing your health and preventing disease, an integrative medicine approach to your heart health can help. Dr. Suhar will explain how emotions affect health and how simple lifestyle changes can dramatically improve your health -- even prevent a heart attack. See http://www.scripps.org/c__wellness-day-2009__integrative-medicine__seminars for more.

videoDescription: The Truth About Trauma is a 28-minute video that showcases the 25-year history of the trauma system in San Diego County. videoDescription: Eighteen-year-old Claire Cordua had just graduated from Westview High School in Rancho Penasquitos. She was spending a leisurely summer hanging out with friends, tutoring, babysitting and getting ready to head off to college. All that changed on July 17, when Claire suffered a massive stroke. Her life was saved twice that day--once by her quick-thinking boyfriend and, then again, by a new physician who had yet to officially start work at Scripps Memorial Hospital La Jolla. This story -- which aired on KGTV Channel 10 on Aug. 13 -- details Claire's life- threatening experience.

videoTitle: Robot Performs Delicate Heart Surgery
videoDescription: A new robotic heart catheter system offers new home for the more than 2.2 million Americans who suffer from atrial fibrillation. The procedure, called a catheter ablation for supraventricular tachycardia, is a common arrhythmia that typically occurs in healthy people and is characterized by palpitations or a racing pulse. Driven by a joystick from a control station next to the patient, physicians at Scripps Memorial Hospital La Jolla are now able to maneuver the robotic catheter with pinpoint precision, much like a video game.
tags: heart,cardiology,cardiac,robot,arrhythmia,atrial fibrillation,atrial flutter,michael Porter
caption: false

videoTitle: Economy Having Impact on Patients Seeking Rehab
videoDescription: The Scripps McDonald Center, a 28-day residential treatment and detox program for drugs and alcohol, is experiencing a decline in admissions as a result of the poor economy. Center officials believe the reasons for the reduction is due to the fact that people are having difficulty paying for the program and because the benefits offered through insurance companies are becoming more challenging. Conversely, admissions to the detox unit have spiked by 30 percent because it is considered a "medical benefit" and much easier to get approval from by the insurance companies. Watch this story as it appeared on KGTV Channel 10...
tags: rehab,economy,alcohol,alcoholism,drugs,rehabilitation,detox,McDonald Center,Scripps
caption: false

videoTitle: National Time Out Day 2009 at Scripps Memorial Hospital La Jolla
videoDescription: The surgical team at Scripps Memorial Hospital La Jolla created and implemented a new check list for our Time Out process based on the World Health Organization's three part check list. We designed our check lists to be specialty-specific to address the unique issues of each surgical specialty. To augment our efforts in implementing the check lists by our OR teams and improving our Time Out process, we created a video outlining the entire process from pre-induction of the patient to sign out. We have used this video to educate staff and physicians to ensure adherence to the process as well as consistency in utilization of the Time Out process.
tags: OR,Checklist,national,time,out,day,scripps,health,memorial,hospital,la,jolla
caption: false

videoTitle: Woman with Severe Deformity Given New Face & New Outlook
videoDescription: See Scripps.org/ana for more. As many as 100,000 Americans suffer from neurofibromatosis, often inaccurately identified as "Elephant Man's Disease". videoTitle: Miracle Mom with Broken Neck Delivers Baby
videoDescription: On Feb. 11, 2009, Tanja Rose gave birth to a healthy baby girl. videoTitle: Scripps Health-Dr. Sunil Rayan, Vascular Surgeon
videoDescription: Dr. Sunil Rayan talks about the heart such as common procedures, recent advances, preventative measures, and challenges. Nationally recognized physicians at Scripps in San Diego provide comprehensive medical management for patients with congenital heart defects (CHD). Scripps cardiologists help patients manage CHD through diagnosis, coordination of care and referrals to partner providers in San Diego and the region.
